stories.text: I am wondering how successful computer scientists working in research positions plan their research projects and careers in the face of uncertainty and career pressures such as external deadlines and publication expectations.  Time estimation is a notoriously difficult problem in software development and in research, yet managers, deans, and other people who evaluate the performance of researchers for hiring/firing/compensation purposes need researchers to be able to make accurate estimates of the time and effort it takes to complete their work.  "Publish or perish" is the reality for researchers to earn a living doing research, but competitive conferences have acceptance rates in the 10%-30% range.  How do researchers manage these performance expectations without "perishing"?
stories.title: Ask HN: How to Plan Research Projects and Careers

stories.text: A while ago (maybe 3-4 years ago) someone made a post that showed a large map where a chemist noted all possible ways to transform a family of chemicals into each other. The post was made to showcase the impressive amount of complexity in the world and in other fields that we might not be aware of. Does anyone know what I'm looking for?
stories.title: Ask HN: HN-Post of two large maps showing chemical transformations
Breaking the Monolith at Twitch: Part One
